title-group.article-title: Epigenetic Disorder May Cause Downregulation of HOXA10 in the Eutopic Endometrium of Fertile Women With Endometriosis

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, The Affiliated Hospital of Nantong University, Nantong, Jiangsu, China
2Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, The Maternal and Child Health Hospital of Nantong University, Nantong, Jiangsu, China
3Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, The People’s Hospital of Haian, Haian, Jiangsu, Haian, China
*The authors contributed equally to the study

author-notes.corresp: Yuquan Zhang, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Affiliated Hospital of Nantong University, Jiangsu, Nantong, 226001 China Email: jsnt_zhangyuquan@yahoo.com.cn

abstract.p: HOXA10 is an important gene for endometrial receptivity and plays a regulatory role in the adult female reproductive tract. It is regulated by epigenetic modulation in the CpG clusters of promoter in some cases. The aim of this study was to investigate HOXA10 expression and the epigenetic regulation in the eutopic endometrium of fertile women with endometriosis by quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and Western blot. The effect of 5-azacytidine (5-ac), a demethylation agent on HOXA10 expression was determined on endometrium stromal cells (ESCs) from these women with endometriosis. Results revealed that in normal endometrium (NE), HOXA10 messenger RNA (mRNA) and protein expression at the secretory phase were significantly higher than that at the proliferative phase. The HOXA10 mRNA and protein expression in the eutopic endometrium of endometriosis were significantly lower than in NE. The HOXA10 mRNA and protein levels in cultured stromal cells from endometriosis in vitro were significantly increased in a 5-ac treatment group compared with a nontreatment group. Our results indicated that the level of HOXA10 decrease in the eutopic endometrium of patients with endometriosis. Upregulation of HOXA10 in ESCs after treatment with 5-ac suggests that HOXA10 expression is controlled by methylation of the promoter. An epigenetic aberration is likely the main cause of endometriosis.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Endometriosis is one of the most common chronic and benign gynecological disorders. It affects 5% to 10% of women at reproductive age.1 Endometriosis can decrease the receptivity of endometrium, hinder the development of oocyte and embryo, and impair the function of uterine tubes, and increasing the chances of infertility.2 It is also linked with lower pregnancy rates in women undergoing in vitro fertilization.3 However, so far, the specific mechanisms that account for the lower pregnancy rate related to endometriosis are poorly understood and the most common treatment for infertility caused by endometriosis is surgical removal of endometriotic tissue and/or assisted reproductive technology. Many studies on endometriosis-associated infertility focus on the altered peritoneal environment, immune function, poor oocyte quality, reduced endometrial receptivity, and altered gene expression. Reduced endometrial receptivity is one of the most important causes of endometriosis-associated infertility. Endometrial receptivity is a multiple event. It involves changes in the expression of genes related to the attachment of trophectoderm to the uterine luminal epithelium and superficial glandular epithelium, modification of the phenotype of uterine stromal cells, silencing of PGR and ESR1 genes, suppression of genes for immune recognition, alterations in membrane permeability to enhance conceptus–maternal exchange of factors, increased endometrium revascularization and activation of genes for nutrient transport into the uterine lumen, and enhanced signaling for pregnancy recognition.4

The HOXA10 is an Abd B-like Hox gene and a member of the homeobox family. It is expressed in the developing genitourinary system in vertebrates and has a regulatory role in the adult female reproductive tract.5 HOXA10 is also an important gene for endometrial receptivity.6,7 Null mutations of HOXA10 in mice cause female infertility, primarily due to defective implantation and decidualization.8 HOXA10 acts as a transcription factor, regulating expression of genes such as cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 1A,9 Wnt pathway components,10 integrin β3,11 FK506-binding protein 4,12 insulin-like growth factor-binding protein 1,13 and empty spiracles homolog 2.14 These genes are important in endometrial decidualization, receptivity establishment, embryo localization, and vasopermeability. The HOXA10 expression in the eutopic endometrium of infertile patients with endometriosis is significantly lower than in normal endometrium (NE).15,16 Recent studies demonstrate that epigenetic alteration might be responsible for this aberration by elevating DNA methylation in the CpG clusters of a HOXA10 gene promoter.13,17 However, whether the epigenetic disorder is involved in the HOXA10 expression in eutopic endometrium of patients with endometriosis is unclear.

5-Azacytidine (5-ac) is a pyrimidine nucleoside analog discovered more than 40 years ago.18 It inhibits phenol-o-methyl shift enzyme activity of DNA methylation and can activate methylation deactivation of genes. Currently, it is widely used in gene methylation experiments including studies on patients with endometriosis.19,20 However, no report has addressed HOXA10 expression in the endometriotic eutopic endometrium treated with 5-ac.

This study investigated the expression of HOXA10 messenger RNA (mRNA) and proteins in the eutopic endometrium of fertile patients with endometriosis and the effect of 5-azacytidine (5-ac) on HOXA10 expression in eutopic endometrial stromal cells cultured in vitro.

sec.title: Ethics
sec.p: This study was approved by the institutional review board of the Affiliated Hospital of Nantong University. Written informed consent for the use of tissue was obtained from each woman involved in the study.

sec.title: Samples
sec.p: Normal endometrial tissue was collected from 12 fertile women without endometriosis, including 6 samples collected during the mid-secretory phase (normal endometrial in secretory phase, NES; days 20-22) and 6 samples was collected during the mid-proliferative phase (normal endometrial in proliferative phase, NEP; days 9-11) of the menstrual cycle. Eutopic endometrium was collected from 12 fertile patients including 6 samples from the mid-secretory phase (endometriotic eutopic endometrium in the secretory phase, EEES; days 20-22) and 6 from the mid-proliferative phase (endometriotic eutopic endometrium in the proliferative phase, EEEP; days 9-11) of the menstrual cycle.

Samples were obtained immediately after surgery, placed in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80°C for RNA and protein extraction. At the same time, endometrial stromal cells (ESCs) were established as primary cultures from the 6 cases of EEES. Some EEES samples were collected in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) and taken to the tissue culture laboratory for ESC isolation. The mean age of the women was not significantly different in any group. No patients received any preoperative hormonal therapy. All samples were processed for histological examination to confirm the menstrual cycle phase.

sec.title: Primary Endometrial Stromal Cell Culture
sec.p: The ESCs from 6 women at EEES were isolated using a previously reported protocol with minor modifications.21 Briefly, tissues were rinsed in PBS, minced, and digested with 4 mg/mL collagenase (Sigma, St Louis, Missouri) and DNase (Sigma) at 37°C for 1 hour. The ESCs were separated from epithelial cells by draining through 100 and 40 µm sieves, then suspended in Dulbecco modified Eagle medium (DMEM)/F12 1:1 containing 10% fetal bovine serum (both from Invitrogen, Grand Island, New York) and cultured in a humidified atmosphere with 5% CO2 in air at 37°C. The purity of ESC was determined by morphology and immunofluorescence staining using antibodies against vimentin (1:100; Abcam 8979, Hongkong Ltd.) and cytokeratin (1:100; Abcam 9221, Hongkong Ltd.).

sec.title: Western Blot Analysis
sec.p: Tissues were washed in ice-cold PBS and suspended in a protein extraction reagent (Pierce, Rockford, Illinois). Lysates were centrifuged at 15 700g for 10 minutes. Equal amounts of proteins (15 µg) were resolved in 10% arc-bis gels, transferred to polyvinylidene difluoride membranes, and incubated with anti-human HOXA10 antibody (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Santa Cruz, California; 1:500 dilution). Anti-β-actin antibody served as a loading control. Detection was performed using a SuperSignal West Femto, Maximum Sensitivity Substrate System (Pierce). Protein band intensity was quantified using Quantity One Analysis software (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Los Angeles, California).

sec.title: RNA Extraction and Quantitative Analysis by Real-Time-PCR
sec.p: Total RNA was isolated from tissues and ESCs using RISOTM RNA reagent (Biomics Biotechnologies Co. Ltd. Jiangsu, China) following the manufacturer’s instructions. RNA was reverse-transcribed and amplified using an EzOmics One-Step qualitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) kit (Biomics) in a Bio-Rad iQ5 sequence system (BioRad, USA). The HOXA10 expression was detected with glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) as an internal control. Briefly, 0.4 µg of total RNA was amplified in a 25 µL reaction with 400 nmol/L of primers (HOXA10-forward: 5′-ACAAGCACACCACAATTCTCC-3′ and HOXA10-reverse: 5′-ATCCAAACAATGTCTCCCTTCTC-3′; GAPDH-forward:5′-GAAGGTGAAGGTCGGAGTC-3′ and GAPDH-reverse: 5′-GAAGATGGTGATGGGATTTC-3′). The thermocyler program was 3 minutes at 95°C; 45 amplification cycles (10 seconds at 94°C, 30 seconds at 58°C, and 30 seconds at 78°C with fluorescent detection); 1 minute at 95°C; 1 minute at 55°C; and 30 second at 0.5°C increments from 55 to 95°C to determine the melting curve. Relative quantification of mRNA was performed using the comparative threshold (CT) cycles method. Comparative threshold was used to determine the mRNA level normalized to the average mRNA level in ESCs. The mRNA levels were expressed as an n-fold difference. For each sample, the gene CT value was normalized using the formula: CT = CT HOXA10 − CT GAPDH. To determine the relative expression levels, the following formula was used: CT = CT sample − CT calibrator. This value was used to plot the gene expression employing the formula 2−CT.

sec.title: 5-Azacytidine Treatments
sec.p: The 6 cases of secretory phase ESCs (EEES) were divided into 2 groups (treated and nontreated). To determine the best concentrations for 5-ac, all ESCs were cultured in serum-free DMEM/F12 medium for 24 hours. Treated ESCs were treated with 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 6, or 8 μg/mL of the DNA methyltransferase (DNMT) inhibitor, 5-ac (Sigma) for 5 days. The duration of drug interaction was based on previous reports.19 Medium was changed daily.

Cells were counted with the trypan blue dye exclusion method. Cells were trypsinized and washed with PBS. An aliquot (50 μL) of cell suspensions was incubated with the same volume of trypan blue and cells were counted under a light microscopy with a hemocytometer. Based on cell counts, we chose a suitable concentration of 5-ac for further experiments. The EEES samples were treated or not treated with the chosen concentration of 5-ac. After 5 days, total RNA was extracted for quantitative real time (RT)-PCR and Western blot. All experiments were conducted in triplicate and repeated 3 times.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Student t tests were used to compare gene expression between the 2 groups. P < .05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: The HOXA10 Endometrium mRNA Expression at Different Menstrual Cycle Phases
sec.p: In NE, quantitative RT-PCR showed that HOXA10 mRNA expression was significantly higher at the secretory phase (NES) than the proliferative phase (NEP; P < .05). However, this was not detected in EEE samples from women with endometriosis. The EEE samples at the secretory phase (n = 6; EEES) expressed a similar level of HOXA10 mRNA transcripts as those at the proliferative phase (n = 6; EEEP) from women with endometriosis (P > .05; Figure 1).

caption.p: HOXA10 messenger RNA (mRNA) expression by real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) in normal endometrium (NE) and endometriotic eutopic endometrium (EEE). HOXA10 mRNA expression in the NE at secretory phase (NES) was significantly higher than in the NE at proliferative phase (NEP; P < .05). No significant difference was seen for HOXA10 mRNA expression at the secretory phase of the endometriotic eutopic endometrium (EEES) compared to the proliferative phase of the endometriotic eutopic endometrium (EEEP; P > .05). In HOXA10 mRNA expression in normal versus endometriotic eutopic endometrium, NES expressed significantly higher transcripts than EEES (P < .05), and NEP expressed higher HOXA10 mRNA than EEEP (P < .05).

sec.title: The HOXA10 mRNA Expression in the Endometrium in Normal Health and Eutopic Endometrium Endometriosis
sec.p: Quantitative RT-PCR analysis revealed that NE samples expressed significantly higher levels of HOXA10 mRNA than EEE samples, both at the secretory (P < .05) and proliferative phases (P < .05; Figure 1).

sec.title: The HOXA10 Protein Endometrium Levels in Different Menstrual Cycle Phases
sec.p: Western blot analysis showed that the protein level of HOXA10 at NES was significantly higher than at NEP in NE samples (P < .01). In EEE samples, the protein level of HOXA10 at EEES was higher than EEEP, although this was not significant (P > .05). The results are shown in figure 2.

sec.title: The HOXA10 Protein Levels in Endometrium in Normal Health and Eutopic Endometrium Endometriosis
sec.p: Western blots showed that NE samples expressed significantly higher levels of HOXA10 protein than EEE samples, not only at the NES (P < .05) but at NEP (P < .05; Figure 2).

caption.p: HOXA10 protein expression by Western blot in normal endometrium (NE) and endometriotic eutopic endometrium (EEE). (A) Proteins were extracted from NE at secretory phase (NES), NE at proliferative phase (NEP), endometriotic eutopic endometrium at secretory phase (EEES) and endometriotic eutopic endometrium at proliferative phase (EEEP) and subjected to Western blot. β-Actin protein was assayed in parallel as an internal control. (B) Quantitative analysis of average HOXA10 protein level normalized by β-actin in each group. HOXA10 protein in NES was significantly higher than in NEP (P < .05). No significant difference was seen for HOXA10 protein levels in EEES compared to EEEP (P = .05). However, HOXA10 protein in NES and NEP were significantly higher than in EEES (P < .05) and EEEP, respectively (P < .05).

sec.title: Induction of HOXA10 Expression by 5-ac in Eutopic Endometrium Endometriosis
sec.p: The ESC primary cultures were established for 6 cases of EEES. Cell viability was determined by the trypan blue exclusion method after treatment with 0, 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 6, or 8 μg/mL of 5-ac. Table 1 shows that treatment with more than 4 μg/mL of 5-ac dramatically decreased the number of viable cells (P < .01). In contrast, when cells were exposed to 5-ac at less than 1 μg/mL, no significant reduction was observed (P > .05). In all ESC cultures, treatment with 2 μg/mL 5-ac significantly enhanced HOXA10 expression compared with nontreated groups at both the mRNA level by quantitative RT-PCR (Figure 3A and B; P < .05), and at the protein level by Western blot (Figure 3C and D; P < .05).

caption.p: Induction of HOXA10 messenger RNA (mRNA) and protein in 6 samples of endometrium stromal cells (ESCs) of EEES by 5-azacytidine. (A) Real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for HOXA10 mRNA in 6 samples of treated ESCs and in 6 samples of nontreated ESCs. Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) mRNA was assayed as an internal control. (B) Quantitative analysis of pooled data showed that average HOXA10 mRNA levels normalized to GAPDH in treated ESCs were significantly elevated compared to nontreated ESCs (control; P < .01). (C) Western blot of HOXA10 protein in 6 samples of treated ESCs and 6 samples of nontreated ESCs. β-Actin protein was assayed as an internal control. (D) Quantitative analysis of pooled data showed that average HOXA10 protein normalized to β-actin in treated ESCs was significantly increased compared to nontreated ESCs (control; P < .05).
The Viable ESCs Numbers After Treatment With Various Concentrations of 5-Azacytidinea

fn.p: a ESCs viability was determined by the trypan blue exclusion method after treatment without or with various concentrations (0.5, 1, 2, 4, 6, and 8 μg/mL) of 5-azacytidine.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Primary heritable genetic information is dictated by the DNA sequence that is packed into chromatin. The basic repeating unit of chromatin is a nucleosome consisting of 146 to 147 base pairs of DNA wrapped around a histone octamer. Both DNA and histone proteins can undergo various postsynthetic modifications. These modifications, along with histone variants and nucleosome remodelers, have the ability to strongly influence chromatin structure and transcriptional regulation without changing the underlying DNA sequence, a process called epigenetic regulation. Epigenetic regulation can be roughly separated into 3 interrelated layers: nucleosome positioning, histone modifications, and DNA methylation.22–24 DNA methylation is probably the most extensively studied epigenetic mark and plays an important role in genomic imprinting. In mammalian cells, a methyl group is covalently added to cytosine in the context of CpG (cytosine-phosphate-guanine) dinucleotides in somatic cells.22 Nearly 60% of mammalian gene promoters are located in CpG islands.25 DNA methylation of these CpG-rich promoters silences gene expression by changing the accessibility of DNA to transcription factors or by recruiting additional silencing-associated proteins.26

A previous study27 tested the hypothesis of alteration in DNA methylation in the endometriotic endometrium. DNA methylation was confirmed as a mechanism responsible for severely increased ESR2 mRNA levels. The methylation of a CpG island in the ESR2 promoter region is a primary mechanism responsible for differential expression of ESR2 in endometriosis and the endometrium. A classical CpG island occurs in the promoter region of the SF-1 gene, and promoter methylation is a major mechanism of SF-1 silencing in NE cells and aberrant expression in endometriotic cells.20 Among the factors involved in infertility, endometrial receptivity decrease is responsible for approximately two thirds of implantation failures.28 In patients with endometriosis, markers for endometrial receptivity are altered including HOXA10, HOXA11, SOD, glycodelin, OPN, integrin β3, and IGFBP-1.29–31 HOXA10 expression is regulated by estrogen and progesterone in the endometrium and its expression increases in the mid-secretory phase of the menstrual cycle.32 This was also confirmed in our study. We not only confirmed that HOXA10 mRNA and protein expression at the secretory phase was significantly higher than at the proliferative phase in NE, but also found that both HOXA10 mRNA and protein levels were significantly lower in the eutopic endometriotic endometrium of fertile women. This finding was consistent with a previous study showing significant downregulation of HOXA10 in infertile patients with endometriosis.33

Recent studies demonstrate that hypermethylation in the CpG islands of the promoter of HOXA10 causes a decrease in its expression. Epigenetic alteration might be responsible for this aberration by elevating the DNA methylation in the CpG clusters of the HOXA10 gene promoter.34,35 Block et al36 found that increased levels of DNA methylation in both the promoter and the intron of HOXA10 were observed after in utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol, in which another estrogenic endocrine disrupting compounds. However, Bromer et al’s37 study suggests that hypomethylation of the HOXA10 gene is a mechanism responsible for bisphenol A related altered developmental programming of the HOXA10 gene. Hastings et al asserted that c-fos overexpression induces abnormal methylation of genes such as ESR, PR, and HOXA10 in the early stage of endometriosis.38 Wu et al found an aberrant methylation status in 3 fragments in 2 regions of the HOXA10 promoter in the eutopic endometrium of patients with endometriosis compared to the NE from patients without endometriosis.17 One mechanism for the diminished expression of HOXA10 in endometriosis is hypermethylation of the gene.

Increasing knowledge of the action mechanism of 5-ac indicates that lower doses of 5-ac could act as DNMT inhibitors with minimal effect on DNA synthesis. Two main mechanisms of antineoplastic action have been identified for 5-ac, namely the capacity to incorporate directly into RNA with subsequent disruption of RNA metabolism, and to inhibit DNA methylation. The second mechanism of action, the inhibition of DNA methylation, is by trapping DNMTs. In general, DNA methylation refers to the addition of a methyl group to the cytosine residue of a CpG site. The degree of methylation of CpG islands plays a role in the control of gene transcription. Usually, fully methylated sites are associated with suppression of gene expression, while hypomethylated or unmethylated CpG islands are linked to active transcription. Forming a tight-binding complex, 5-ac irreversibly binds to methyltransferase. It inhibits the enzyme in its progression along the DNA duplex and functionally depletes it from the cell. Consequently, unmethylated DNA can lead to the transcription of previously quiescent genes.18,39

In this study, we used the DNMT inhibitor 5-ac to modulate the methylation status of the HOXA10 promoter in primary ESCs from the eutopic endometrium of endometriosis patients. We found that HOXA10 mRNA and protein expression were markedly upregulated in the EEES after treatment with 5-ac, indirectly confirming that HOXA10 hypermethylation exists in the eutopic endometrium of endometriosis patients. To our knowledge, this is the first evidence that epigenetic modification enhances HOXA10 expression. This observation suggested that a disorder of a methylation-dependent suppression mechanism could cause downregulation of HOXA10 in EEES.

In conclusion, this study demonstrated that HOXA10 mRNA and protein expression levels in EEE were significantly lower in fertile patients affected with endometriosis. However, demethylation of cultured ESCs by 5-ac treatment significantly increased HOXA10 mRNA and protein expression for EEES. This study is a first attempt to determine whether epigenetic modification by 5-ac enhanced HOXA10 expression. Future studies are necessary to confirm the findings in larger samples and to investigate the promoter in vivo before and after 5-ac treatment.

fn.p: The authors received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
